Description: Lower body fragment of an Attic black-figured pottery closed vase, possibly an olpe; heavy wheelmarks on the interior. Lion and floral; remaining are one foreleg of the feline to right and the calyx of the lotus and adjoining tendrils; added red on lotus. Glossy black below with one reserved band.
Producer name: Attributed to the Manner of: The Gorgon Painter (Venit)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit: 'Manner of the Gorgon Painter; a replica of Oxford G 550 (CVA Great Britain 9: pl. 1 fig. 30; ABV 13, 41), also from Naukratis, which is either by the Gorgon Painter or by another artist painting in his manner.'
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 80 no. 268 pl. 61)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 144 fig. 5)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1210)
